summary: I just read WoS #58 and... something happened... something I thought never would... you think this things happen to toher...
body:
I just read WoS #58 and… something happened… something I thought never would… you think this things happen to toher people, never to you, and then… I agree with something someone in the comments section said. The Grizzly should come back as an ally.

No, but really, the issue was heart-warming, especially the ending, where Max realized Spidey had thrown the fight and was okay with it. 

The thing with Kristy was nice, too, but… what exactly are they planning to do now? Like, the only people who will take care of her now are Peter and MJ (and Aunt May, but she’s literally throwing people out of the house to give Nathan a peaceful last months, so she probably won’t want to take her in because of that), they’ll have to become their surrogate parents. They even changed her age so that she’s be 13 instead of 16, so it’s not even like they can say “well, she can emancipate/ it’ll only be 2 years/ whatever”. How do they deal with that?

Like, the only people who will take care of her now are Peter and MJ (and Aunt May, but she’s literally throwing people out of the house to give Nathan a peaceful last months, so she probably won’t want to take her in because of that), they’ll have to become their surrogate parents. They even changed her age so that she’s be 13 instead of 16, so it’s not even like they can say “well, she can emancipate/ it’ll only be 2 years/ whatever”. How do they deal with that?

maybe she gets them as a boon from a spider-themed fairy
summary: So I saw that some people were making Spider-Verse OCs. Earth-347 is a world in which the figures we recognize from Earth-616...
caption:
So I saw that some people were making Spider-Verse OCs.

Earth-347 is a world in which the figures we recognize from Earth-616 take the place of characters in fairy tales. In Petra Portner’s case, she was only seventeen years old when she took a walk through the Enchanted Forest to bring her Aunties a basket of goodies. Her carelessness on the path ended with a wolf eating her Aunt Ben, which is a thing that happens pretty often in the Enchanted Forest, and ever since Petra has decided to patrol the Enchanted Forest to protect all who pass through it.

So yeah maybe I did just decide to fuse Spider-Man with Fables because the only comic series I’ve read all the way through was Fables what about it

summary:
Toxin: Grandpa Venom says I can’t see my birth giver anymore. 
Peter Parker: oh dude, that sucks. Why?
Toxin, shrugging: keeps...
body:
Toxin: Grandpa Venom says I can’t see my birth giver anymore.

Peter Parker: oh dude, that sucks. Why?

Toxin, shrugging: keeps trying to kill me and shit.

Peter Parker, eyes wide: oOh

summary: All in all, I think the main message/theme of acceptance that both SSM #156 and WoS #57 tried to make was better handled by...
body:
All in all, I think the main message/theme of acceptance that both SSM #156 and WoS #57 tried to make was better handled by Web.First of all, in Spec, the only threatening thing Peter did was follow Banjo to the settling, which is not a point I’m making because I blame the settlers, but because the final message of “I shouldn’t have judged you for looking weird and you shouldn’t have thrown me in the same lot of those who hurt you before without knowing me” was kind of… lacking? Considering the only thing Peter had done was make mean remarks in his own mind? In Web, however, well, the message wasn’t exactly the same, so there’s no real equivalence to that mistake. But the only two things I can complain about are minor (they didn’t even bother to draw the skeleton shadow inside of Skinhead before it became relevant) or maybe understandable when taking into consideration the in-universe context (Peter’s negative attitude towards fighting against the neo-nazis, even as he was against them - the police actually went and arrested them, instead of letting them spew their shit. In this day and age, that’s not a sure thing, but in the comic it was, so getting into fights with them would only have gotten them into trouble for fighting without really accomplishing anything, because the skinheads were going to be stopped anyway. I mean, besides getting to punch a neo-nazi. Also, it was a different time, so the danger of nazism wasn’t as pressing).

In both cases, however, the message would have worked better if Peter, or whoever delivered the final speech, had been more involved: in the case of Spec, he could have actually tried to hurt Banjo because he thought he was a monster; in Web, Bob could have been the one to give it. The problem with Super-hero speeches is that you risk having the hero be above everything. With Peter, that wasn’t usually the case because they were born out of real emotion - they were spontaneous, and sometimes, more than speeches, they were more like mic drops. These last two issues, I was almost expecting him to look at the front, like at a camera. He was too distant from the real issue for it to sound like anything but some super-hero wisdom. It’s what I meant when I said he’s been a side-character in the stories: they don’t really afect him.

reblog.comment:

tags: into the spider verse the official movie special
summary: Can you tell us about your responsibilities as animation supervisor onSpider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse? Josh Beveridge: The...
caption:
Can you tell us about your responsibilities as animation supervisor onSpider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse?

Josh Beveridge: The responsibilities shift depending on where we are at in production, but the overriding aim of my job is to push the character animation to be the best it can be. My day-to-day challenges include making sure the characters are consistent and helping to ensure the performances match the director’s vision. I’m basically a cheerleader for animation. I’ve been working on the film since 2016 helping to interpret the designs and paintings into animation. We have a bold, different visual style to this movie. It took over a year for us to develop that technology. We wanted to try something fresh. This has been a tough project, but we’re hoping it will be a new frontier.

How big was this project for you?

This has been a pretty all-consuming job for the last two years, but I wouldn’t have it any other way. It’s a dream job - the ten year old me is out of his mind with excitement right now.

How do you coordinate a team of that size?

We have an amazing team. They all care and they’re all hard-working. A lot of these folks relocated to be a part of this project. When folks are inspired it makes hard work easier.

What are your favorite elements of animation that have been developed for this movie?

One of the things I really love is that we’re animating on twos [Editor’s note: Ones, twos, and threes refer to how long a single image holds on camera for in relationship to frames per second. Ones mean every single frame is different, so at 24 frames per second you’ll have 24 individual and unique drawings with that second. Twos means that something holds for two frames, rather than one].

There’s something pretty great about being on twos – it’s crisper, it’s pop art and every decision made on this project is based on the look of the comic books. Pop art graphic clarity is one of those things that we felt was critical. Getting two to work for more complicated things like hair or cloth simulations as well as camera operation was quite a collaborative feat. Once we got to a process where twos could be a thing we could modulate within a shot it became strictly a creative call for how and when to do it. Every single department in this movie rolled up their sleeves and just took it apart to figure out how to make it all work.

Is there anything new that you get to do with the characters that you wouldn’t have been able to without the new animation technology?

Our new “Inkline” tools would be a huge one. To make things feel even more like a comic book we knew we wanted inklines. We built several different ways to make a drawn line exist in 3D space with and around our characters and pandoras box has really opened up to all kinds of expressive possibilities we never had before. The power of the drawn line in incredible. A simple line can exaggerate an emotion, clarify an action, or describe a form. Having this tool in the hands of each animator has proven to be incredibly powerful.

Do you ever piece roughs together with storyboards or even clips from other animated films or shows to give the directors a general idea of what it will look like?

Absolutely. I do not waste time, so we use any technique we can to get ideas out there, to throw those ideas out. We have some people who sketch out ideas and take photos with their phones and submit those so we can look at them in the context of the shots. Other people talk through what they are designing. And some people take primitive balls or blocks and animate those just to give us a sense of how energy passes through the scenes, and what kind of movement we will be doing.

Some of the animators even film themselves acting out scenes as a reference.

There’s some really good ones that I want to put into a second version of the film that is just made up of those! I look at influences from all over the place. It also helps rule out ideas, which is just as helpful as finding the answers.

Are there times when the voice-acting changes and shifts direction for your team?

A lot of performances are workshopped and they improve as we go, but ideally when animation starts it’s with a final version of the reads. That is the most straight-forward way to do it. Most of the time that is the case, but sometimes because of schedule constraints we start animation to a temp track and potentially adjust one way or another afterwards. These things get built up as we go along.

[Source]

Absolutely. I do not waste time, so we use any technique we can to get ideas out there, to throw those ideas out. We have some people who sketch out ideas and take photos with their phones and submit those so we can look at them in the context of the shots. Other people talk through what they are designing. And some people take primitive balls or blocks and animate those just to give us a sense of how energy passes through the scenes, and what kind of movement we will be doing.

Some of the animators even film themselves acting out scenes as a reference.

There’s some really good ones that I want to put into a second version of the film that is just made up of those! I look at influences from all over the place. It also helps rule out ideas, which is just as helpful as finding the answers.

Are there times when the voice-acting changes and shifts direction for your team?

A lot of performances are workshopped and they improve as we go, but ideally when animation starts it’s with a final version of the reads. That is the most straight-forward way to do it. Most of the time that is the case, but sometimes because of schedule constraints we start animation to a temp track and potentially adjust one way or another afterwards. These things get built up as we go along.

[Source]

trail.content_raw:
Can you tell us about your responsibilities as animation supervisor onSpider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse?

Josh Beveridge: The responsibilities shift depending on where we are at in production, but the overriding aim of my job is to push the character animation to be the best it can be. My day-to-day challenges include making sure the characters are consistent and helping to ensure the performances match the director’s vision. I’m basically a cheerleader for animation. I’ve been working on the film since 2016 helping to interpret the designs and paintings into animation. We have a bold, different visual style to this movie. It took over a year for us to develop that technology. We wanted to try something fresh. This has been a tough project, but we’re hoping it will be a new frontier.

How big was this project for you?

This has been a pretty all-consuming job for the last two years, but I wouldn’t have it any other way. It’s a dream job - the ten year old me is out of his mind with excitement right now.

How do you coordinate a team of that size?

We have an amazing team. They all care and they’re all hard-working. A lot of these folks relocated to be a part of this project. When folks are inspired it makes hard work easier.

What are your favorite elements of animation that have been developed for this movie?

One of the things I really love is that we’re animating on twos [Editor’s note: Ones, twos, and threes refer to how long a single image holds on camera for in relationship to frames per second. Ones mean every single frame is different, so at 24 frames per second you’ll have 24 individual and unique drawings with that second. Twos means that something holds for two frames, rather than one].

There’s something pretty great about being on twos – it’s crisper, it’s pop art and every decision made on this project is based on the look of the comic books. Pop art graphic clarity is one of those things that we felt was critical. Getting two to work for more complicated things like hair or cloth simulations as well as camera operation was quite a collaborative feat. Once we got to a process where twos could be a thing we could modulate within a shot it became strictly a creative call for how and when to do it. Every single department in this movie rolled up their sleeves and just took it apart to figure out how to make it all work.

Is there anything new that you get to do with the characters that you wouldn’t have been able to without the new animation technology?

Our new “Inkline” tools would be a huge one. To make things feel even more like a comic book we knew we wanted inklines. We built several different ways to make a drawn line exist in 3D space with and around our characters and pandoras box has really opened up to all kinds of expressive possibilities we never had before. The power of the drawn line in incredible. A simple line can exaggerate an emotion, clarify an action, or describe a form. Having this tool in the hands of each animator has proven to be incredibly powerful.

Do you ever piece roughs together with storyboards or even clips from other animated films or shows to give the directors a general idea of what it will look like?

Absolutely. I do not waste time, so we use any technique we can to get ideas out there, to throw those ideas out. We have some people who sketch out ideas and take photos with their phones and submit those so we can look at them in the context of the shots. Other people talk through what they are designing. And some people take primitive balls or blocks and animate those just to give us a sense of how energy passes through the scenes, and what kind of movement we will be doing.

Some of the animators even film themselves acting out scenes as a reference.

There’s some really good ones that I want to put into a second version of the film that is just made up of those! I look at influences from all over the place. It also helps rule out ideas, which is just as helpful as finding the answers.

Are there times when the voice-acting changes and shifts direction for your team?

A lot of performances are workshopped and they improve as we go, but ideally when animation starts it’s with a final version of the reads. That is the most straight-forward way to do it. Most of the time that is the case, but sometimes because of schedule constraints we start animation to a temp track and potentially adjust one way or another afterwards. These things get built up as we go along.

[Source]

[Source]

summary: Miles: Alright, I have a math problem for you. There are seven baby birds in a tree when their mother and father come back. How...
body:
Miles: Alright, I have a math problem for you. There are seven baby birds in a tree when their mother and father come back. How many birds are in the tree now?

*Peter starts crying*

Miles: Oh no, why are you crying?

Peter: I’m sorry, I can’t focus on math right now! I’m just so happy the bird family was reunited!

reblog.comment:

Peter: I’m sorry, I can’t focus on math right now! I’m just so happy the bird family was reunited!

tags: spider man into the spider verse
summary:
Miles Morales Headcanons 
He’s uses Cantu; Someone asked him while he was swinging.
Since Aunt May forgot to add silk lining to...
body:
Miles Morales Headcanons

  • He’s uses Cantu; Someone asked him while he was swinging.
  • Since Aunt May forgot to add silk lining to his suit; he has to carry a Durag with him
  • Whenever he’s in the suit; his hair is in twists.
  • Whenever there’s a block party or a cookout; he always gets a plate.
  • Miles is a sneakerhead. As Spidey, he always gets newest shoes, but he resells them. It would give away his secret identity.
  • Old heads at the barbershop always bother him but he listens to their advice sometimes.
  • He has a Twitter, Instagram, and Tumblr for his art. It’s for fun. He doesn’t think he can do anything with it.
  • Hoteps always bother him because they want to know the source of his powers
  • His favorite pair of sneakers are these white AF1s he customized himself.
  • He wants to dye the tips of his hair blonde but he doesn’t want to give his dad a heart attack.
  • Ever since Eric Garner’s death, Miles doesn’t trust cops at all.    He wished his dad had a different job. They fight about it all the time.
  • While on patrol, He runs like Naturo and bring his sketchbook with him.
  • On twitter, he found a fic about him and since then he’s been constantly reading them. He always cringes when they describe him with silky hair.
